ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: We don't really have a choice...
It's a required course for MCGD 1st years, so of course I'd recommend it to MCGD 1st years. It's just a bunch of general information; the important stuff will be memorable,
It's a disjointed faux-grant help class. Would not recommend if it was not required.
It helped relay important information about grad school and life as a scientist.
Good place to build bonds with your colleagues

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: I think that I didn't learn anything new, though I imagine that it could be useful in evening out the playing field. Seriously, though, it seems better fit for three quick orientation meetings or something... For example, the library session where we learned how to use library resources was absolutely ridiculous. If we haven't learned that PubMed exists so far in our career, I can't imagine how overwhelming everything else would be.

I think this course was relatively helpful for the presentation side of things and also the grant writing side of things. It was not, however, particularly useful for the library research/how to search for papers/maintain papers, because one of the instructors didn't seem to know her stuff very well and the other really only presented one of the many options available to us for maintaining our paper libraries.
I did not find it very helpful and I don't feel that I learned much.
It helped to improve and highlight the importance of skills not normally covered in a typical class (i.e. communication / writing / publishing / etc.)
prepare for the potential questions during scientific research.
